title: What will be Rocket Companies' end-of-day market capitalization on the day of its initial public offering (IPO)?
possible_answers: More than $45 billion but less than $55 billion
Quicken Loans will not have an IPO before 31 October 2020
preds: Raised less than expected but first day of trading saw jump of 22% for shares

Bookbuilding reduced by investors demand, 18-20 USD per share latest offer (20-22USD before, number of shares on offer reduced by one third to 100mn shares instead of 150mn?). "The 39 percent reduction came as investors rejected the company’s valuation, noting it should be priced as a consumer or financial company rather than a technology business, one of the sources said, according to Bloomberg."

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-05/rocket-is-said-to-cut-ipo-to-about-2-billion-from-3-3-billion
100 million shares at $18 = $1.8B. Value of company in low 40’s

There’s anticipation behind the Rocket IPO considering  the boom in recent refinance activity.   Rocket depends on refinance activity and thrives when rates decline.  Rates are currently bottomed out, a similar scenario to when it gained a huge market share.   Fundamentally a retail mortgage company is not at all exciting compared to the tech unicorns or Beyond Meats, but Quicken/Rocket is a household name that has not quietly taken 9% of the overall market since ‘09 and I see the behemoths that pull the strings behind the curtain pumping Rocket up and selling it off a few days later. There’s no dividend on offer but Covid forbearance levels at Rocket range 5% when the industry average is 8%, and it’s a household name among millennials, who I imagine would be targeting to buy the stock as well, so there’s enough positive attributes to create a slightly oversubscribed IPO.

The effect of COVID and the inability of Congress to reach a deal on relief will unload 45 million potential properties on the market via foreclosures and evictions.  There is simply not enough wealth on the positive side to absorb the massive losses of home ownership following the crash of 2008 from which institutional investors became the massive owner of foreclosed properties.
Reflecting current projections estimating a close around $40 billion capitalization.

150 million shares initially
option for an additional 22.5 million shares

Form S-1 received 7 July 2020
Average ballpark time from S-1 to IPO: 5-6 months
Competitor Market Cap, Mature companies ~ 200 Billion
I am thinking it will land around $42 billion, I have left room for it to be over that, though I find it unlikely it will be over $55 billion.
Garbage in Garbage out on this one. Lots of cash on the sidelines looking for vehicles to deploy to.

Low interest rates drives up mortgages, meaning Quicken Loans' business is doing very well. Since interest rates are unlikely to increase in the coming months, that should drive the stock price up substantially. However, depending on the behavior of Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, their sales may take a hit depending on what legislation is passed in the coming months, which may depress the price. It is also unlikely that they will offer dividends, which could also reduce the end-of-day Market Capitalization stats. The uncertainty in the market will also likely take something away from its cap, even though it has thus far performed quite well. That being said, with its large volume of sales and its status as the largest mortgage lender in the country, it likely won't go for less than $35 billion. Historically speaking, however, that benchmark is quite high and likely won't be surpassed by much.
